description: On March 18, Panama announced a nation-wide curfew from 21.00 to 05.00, in attempt to guarantee the safety and health of its citizens and to mitigate the effects of the pandemic.The exceptions to this measure include police and other law enforcement groups, hospitals and health centers, markets and supermarkets, security companies and securities transport and public transport for health reasons or contracted by exempt establishments.

On March 18, Panama announced a nation-wide curfew from 21.00 to 05.00, in attempt to guarantee the safety and health of its citizens and to mitigate the effects of the pandemic.The exceptions to this measure include police and other law enforcement groups, hospitals and health centers, markets and supermarkets, security companies and securities transport and public transport for health reasons or contracted by exempt establishments. On March 23, this curfew was announced to be extended from 17.00 pm to 05.00 am, to take effect the next day on March 24.

Panama enacted nationwide movement restrictions, also referred to as quarantine, effective March 25, 2020. On June 1, the ID number and gender-based movement restrictions were replaced with a 7am to 5pm curfew on Monday through Sunday for all provinces excluding Panama and Panama Oeste.
Panama is implementing a weekend curfew starting Saturday 5pm until Monday 5am in the provinces of Panama and Panama Oeste for the month of July.

On July 21, the Government of Panama announced total quarantine in the provinces of Bocas del Toro, Colon, and Chiriqui on Saturdays and Sundays with curfew from 7pm Friday to 5am Monday every weekend. The curfew from Monday through Friday remains from 7pm until 5am.
The President of Panama and his Cabinet of Ministers formally approve a state of emergency due to COVID-19 on March 13th
Panama will prohibit, starting Monday, March 16, the entry of foreigners who do not have a residency in the country.

The government of Panama and the Ministry of Health announce that on the 22nd of March, all international flights will be suspended for a period of thirty days. This excludes humanitarian flights and those necessary to transport cargo and products, medical-hospital equipment, medicines, vaccines and any other public health supplies necessary to face the pandemic.

The government of Panama and the Ministry of Health announce that on the 22nd of March, all international flights will be suspended for a period of thirty days. This excludes humanitarian flights and those necessary to transport cargo and products, medical-hospital equipment, medicines, vaccines and any other public health supplies necessary to face the pandemic. On June 17, The Government of Panama extended the suspension of international commercial passenger flights to July 22.

On July 17, the Government of Panama extended the suspension of international commercial passenger and domestic charter flights, originally announced on March 26, for an additional 30 days beginning July 22. The previous exceptions for cargo, humanitarian, medical supplies, medical evacuation, and vaccines remain in place.
Panama is implementing sanitary barriers and sanitary checks to confirm regulatorily compliance by extending the rights of government officila son th 16th of March 2020.

On March 23, the Ministry of Health in Panama has been given the legal power to locate people that have tested positive to COVID-19 and place them in specific, isolated places and under the supervision of the medical team.

The Panama health authorities have ordered that anyone who is COVID-19 positive and is found in the supermarket will be detained and forced to transfer to a hotel/hospital. Additionally, their Metrobús card will be canceled and the Panama Solidario voucher will not be paid.
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: Panama has opened its 7th control and traceability center in the province of Colón on July 4th to monitor contagion tracing and implement testing house-by-house to those infected.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
On the 7th of March, Panama's Ministery of Health activated hotline 169. This phone-service functions to register alleged cases, and to answer questions from people who have been in contact with people from at risk countries and are at risk of contracting COVID-19 themselves. 
The hotline will function 24h a day to register cases. The callcenter is available to answer questions between 08.00 and18.00 pm. During this time, phone operators are to work under the guidance of 10 health specialists. UPDATE: On March 29, the Panamese Ministry of Health announced that hotline 169 will now also address the mental health component of COVID-19, and is to be manned by, amongst others, psychiatrists and psychologists from the Ministry of Health itself, the Social Security Fund and the Ministry of Social Development.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

On March 15, the Ministry of Health announced that all elective surgeries are postponed and clinical consultation in all hospitals is to be limited, exempting patients with chronic diseases, those that are in a risk group such as children and pregnant women.

On the 18th of March, President Cortizo of Panama announced his decision to apply a zero tariff policy to for products related to the recommended health and hygiene measures to face the pandemic.
On March 19, Panama's Minister of Health ordered 3,500 units of protective equipment, to be distributed among medical and hospital personnel throughout the province of Veraguas.

description: The Social Security Fund in Panama has launched a home delivery service for medicines for patients with chronic diseases over the age of 65, to take effect on March 21.
The Social Security Fund in Panama has launched a home delivery service for medicines for patients with chronic diseases over the age of 65, to take effect on March 21.
The Social Security Fund in Panama has launched a home delivery service for medicines for patients with chronic diseases over the age of 65, to take effect on March 21.
The Ministry of Health in Panama has appointed 40 new health professionals to attend to patients in home isolation and with mild symptoms.
On March 23, the Government of Panama announced the acquisition of 4000+ test kits to diagnose potential cases of COVID-19.
Panama's Social Security Fund acquires 15 new ventilators.

On April 1, four intensive care specialists were appointed to continue strengthening the 'Protect Yourself Panama Plan', two for the San Miguel Arcángel Hospital, in San Miguelito, and another two for the Nicolás A. Solano Hospital, in La Chorrera.
On April 2, The Panamese Ministry of Health delivered 3000 masks for the users of tram lines 1 and 2 at the San Miguelito Metro station and explained how to use them.

On April 2, the Panamese Ministry of Health announced that a sampling center for COVID-19 came into operation in San Miguelito, where samples are to be taken from people that are referred through the hotline 169. It will operate from 7 in the morning to 6:30 in the afternoon.
On April 4,The Panamese National Directorate for Health Promotion delivered 4,000 masks to the Arraiján district, to be used primarily by people who are at risk.
The Panama Ministry of Health has installed a 20-bed mobile hospital in the province of Darién to help alleviate the over-crowded hospitals due to COVID-19 patients.
On July 7th, Panama received a donation of medicine and surgical equipment from India to serve as medical support for the fight against COVID-19.
On July 7th, Panama received a donation of medicine and surgical equipment from India to serve as medical support for the fight against COVID-19.
On July 7th, Panama received a donation of medicine and surgical equipment from India to serve as medical support for the fight against COVID-19.
The Panama government announced on July 9th that it will be purchasing Remdesivir as treatment for about 1000 COVID-19 patients.
The government of Panama has implemented enhanced screening at all points of entry and exit in the state, including all cruise ships, to reduce the spread of COVID-19, starting on the 10th of March.

On March 14, the Government of Panama announced the establishment of a national diagnostic network to implement mass testing of COVID-19, with the objective of enabling people with symptoms or a known history of contact with a known case to get tested. In all provinces and the capital these tests will be available in major health facilities. Private hospitals with comparable diagnostic capabilities have been authorised to acquire the necessary test kits and conduct tests.

description: On April 2, the Ministry of Health announced a resolution to authorize public and private pharmacies to dispense medications through prescriptions sent by available technological means. Doctors in the public and private sector are authorized to use technological mechanisms to send prescriptions to the pharmacy of the patient's choice.
type_text: This policy allows doctors to send prescriptions to the pharmacy of the patient's choice.

description: Panama is suspending the judicial work in the Second Court of Niñez y Adolescencía of the First Judicial Circuit of Panama starting August 3rd due to the fact that an official of the court tested positive for COVID-19 in order to sanitize the office.
type_text: An official of the second court of Niñez y Adolescencía of the First Judicial Circuit of Panama tested positive for COVID-19. As such, that court has suspended as judicial terms and work as of August 3rd in order to sanitize and disinfect. There is no information on when work will return.

description: As of August 24, the Government of Panama has opened the following sectors of the economy: real estate, wholesale trade, housing development, property appraisal, beauty salons and barber shops (not including esthetics), some private and public construction, non-governmental organizations (NGO’s), mining of non-metals, industry, car repair shops, technical services, and small scale fishing. Religious sites, parks, social areas, and sporting areas are allowed to operate at 25 percent capacity. In Los Santos, Herrera, and Cocle provinces, car sales and professional and administrative services are also authorized. Allbusinesses must meet health and safety requirements. The dates for opening additional sectors of the economy remains unknown.

institution_status: This type of business  ("Construction") is allowed to open with conditions

description: As of August 24, the Government of Panama has opened the following sectors of the economy: real estate, wholesale trade, housing development, property appraisal, beauty salons and barber shops (not including esthetics), some private and public construction, non-governmental organizations (NGO’s), mining of non-metals, industry, car repair shops, technical services, and small scale fishing. Religious sites, parks, social areas, and sporting areas are allowed to operate at 25 percent capacity. In Los Santos, Herrera, and Cocle provinces, car sales and professional and administrative services are also authorized. Allbusinesses must meet health and safety requirements. The dates for opening additional sectors of the economy remains unknown.
